intro: Calochortus clavatus subsp. pallidus, commonly known as the pale globemallow, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a herbaceous perennial that typically grows in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and rocky slopes. The plant features showy, cup-shaped flowers that are usually pale yellow to cream in color, with a distinctive central tuft of hairs. Its leaves are basal, narrow, and covered in fine hairs, which help reduce water loss in arid environments. The species is part of the genus Calochortus, which includes many species of flowering plants known for their ornamental value and ecological importance.
